Do meet your heroes.

Eight years ago, this week, I got to meet my boyhood idol, Seattle Seahawks icon Steve Largent (at a dinner with 10 Pro Football Hall of‚Ä¶
data.text:
üåü Are Scottie Barnes and Trae Young Truly All-Stars? üèÄ As the NBA All-Star Weekend approaches, there's been a lot of buzz surrounding the selections of Scottie Barnes and Trae Young as injury replacements. While both players undoubtedly possess remarkable skills on the court, the question arises: Are they truly deserving of the prestigious title of All-Star? The All-Star designation has historically been reserved for players who consistently demonstrate exceptional performance, leadership, and impact on their respective teams throughout the season. While Barnes and Young have shown flashes of brilliance, their inclusion as injury replacements prompts us to critically assess their overall contributions. Scottie Barnes, the dynamic rookie for the Toronto Raptors, has undeniably made waves with his versatility and energy on the court. However, his statistical performance, while impressive for a rookie, may not yet measure up to the standards typically associated with All-Star status. Similarly, Trae Young of the Atlanta Hawks has showcased incredible offensive prowess and playmaking abilities, but his team's underwhelming performance this season raises questions about the impact of his contributions on the overall success of the squad. As we celebrate the talent and athleticism of all NBA players, it's essential to uphold the integrity of the All-Star designation. While Barnes and Young are undoubtedly talented individuals, perhaps their selection as All-Stars warrants further scrutiny and consideration. What are your thoughts on this matter? Do you believe Scottie Barnes and Trae Young truly deserve to be All-Stars, or do you think their selections as injury replacements raise valid questions about the criteria for such prestigious recognition? Let's discuss! #NBAAllStar #Basketball #SportsAnalysis

The Brotherly Shove! Love it, or hate it... Believe it's a "football play" or not.... It's succeeded for the Eagles at over 90% for the last two seasons! Now, they have yet to break off a Brotherly Shove for a 90 yard touchdown. BUT, it is a play in their playbook that almost always moves the ball forward, or at least doesn't move them backwards. Why? They have the right pieces in the right place (an elite Offensive line and a QB who can squat 700+ lbs.). It's also structured the right way and coached with extreme discipline. Do you have a component of your financial plan that consistently moves the ball forward without going backwards? Have you structured it properly and coached yourself to get it right more than 90% of the time? This piece may not get you the "big play" or a massive win in any given year (as evidenced by how the Eagles' season ended). However, it may be that piece you can lean on when things get rough. It may be a piece of your plan that you can rely on when the going gets tough and you need something to lean on. If you haven't incorporated this piece into your plan, is it time to start? #financialplanning #brotherlylove #brotherlyshove

I attended the National Basketball Association (NBA) game between the Brooklyn Nets and Detroit Pistons for the 2021/2022 season. In the game, one of the players, Kevin Durant, was ejected due to shoving his elbow in the opponent's face. That type of aggression could be categorised as anger aggression, which is a sudden reaction to an opponent‚Äôs aggression (Grange & Kerr, 2010). Strategies called to reduce those reactions are emotional regulation strategies, either pre-competition or post-competition. Selecting the right strategy for a specific context is crucial to achieving personal goals (Kucharski et al., 2018). In this case, Kevin Durant, who is on the list of the 15 all-time scorers in the NBA, is expected to apply the right strategies to control his emotions. However, we must acknowledge that athletes are humans and can react incorrectly in certain circumstances. The right application of emotional regulation strategies will reduce the chances of anger aggression, but mistakes are part of the game. Some players are more likely to react in those situations than others, and identifying those who need more support is crucial, as well as avoiding targets to players when making those mistakes.

Comparison is the thief of joy. Be proud of where YOU are now. It's most likely better than where you were a few short months ago Ben Simmons is a perfect example of how damaging comparisons can be He was unfairly compared to LeBron James from day 1 He was then compared to future MVP Joel Embiid throughout his playing days in Philadelphia He was always seen as a bust, never really living up to scoring expectations of a 1st overall pick But his numbers are better than what people think He was runner up for defensive player of the year in his last year in Philly, (ahead of defensive stalwarts Draymond Green and Giannis) But all we remember is the shot he didn't take üí© ********* Win shares is a stat that encapsulates how many wins a player earned for his team NBA Superstar Devin Booker racked up 18.3 win shares over 255 games during Simmons first 4 years in the league, (Booker's 3rd through 6th years) Simmons accumulated 30.3 win shares over 275 games! Booker has never had a season with as many win shares as either of Simmons' first 2 seasons I am not trying to take anything away from Booker I'm just using numbers to show that Simmons isn't only good in video games üòú I want to celebrate them both As I‚Äôm trying to point out, üçé & üçä Booker is an offensive firecracker Simmons is an athletic marvel who affects both ends of the floor like few can Simmons isn't playing for Philadelphia anymore Let's leave his past where it belongs And he appreciate how well he is playing now 10 points, 11 assists, 8 rebounds in 18 minutes! 0 turnovers or missed shots And the Nets were (+27) in his 18 minutes They were +6 in the 30 minutes without him His impact on the court is epic when he is healthy So let's celebrate him before he gets hurt again ü§ï Not think about how good he would be if he could shoot ü§£ #nba #bensimmons #growth #mindset #injuries #return #techsales #facilities #sports #lessons

Age ain't nothing but a number. Just ask LeBron James, who continues to defy the odds and be the standard bearer of excellence in the NBA despite being the eldest player in the league today. LeBron James embodies this philosophy like no other in the world of sports. The King üëë who turns another year older on December 30 is a testament to resilience, dedication, and the unwavering pursuit of greatness. He continues to redefine what's possible on the court. His enduring dominance challenges the conventional narrative about age and athletic performance. With each game, he not only showcases his unparalleled skills but also serves as an inspiration for all of us to push our boundaries. After winning the inaugural in-season NBA Tournament and being crowned MVP, 38-year old LeBron and the LA Lakers are title contenders once again, with their eyes firmly set on the prize: another NBA championship in June 2024. Why does LeBron matter in the context of age? He possesses a consistency in excellence - day in, day out, his love for the game never waivers and always puts on a show for the fans. He added new elements in his 20 years playing pro ball - his adaptability and commitment to staying at the top of his game serve as a masterclass in navigating change. Beyond the stats and dunks, LeBron is a leader both on and off the court. His leadership qualities and commitment to teamwork are timeless, setting an example for aspiring athletes globally. Lastly, LeBron's journey isn't just for athletes in their prime. It's a beacon of hope for anyone striving for greatness, reminding us that our potential knows no age limit. Let's take a cue from LeBron James and apply his mindset to our own endeavours. Whether in the boardroom, on the field, or pursuing personal goals, let's embrace the belief that age is not a barrier but a badge of experience and wisdom. Keep pushing, keep growing, and remember: Age ain't nothing but a number. LeBron James is living proof that the best is yet to come! We've never met (but I would surely love to someday Los Angeles Lakers), but I carry that mentality as I prepare for another big year in 2024. #AgeAintNuthingButANumber #LeBronJames #Inspiration #Resilience #Excellence #Coinchella #Community #Basketball

***First of four part series about the current state of the WNBA/women‚Äôs basketball from a scriptural perspective*** Angel Reese on 03 JUN 2024 spoke on her and others besides Caitlin Clark helping to expand the popularity of the WNBA. She‚Äôs justified in her stance and her role, for‚Ä¶. 1) ‚Ä¶.Her arrival after the 2022 season led LSU from a [A] second round team in 2022 (same as Caitlin Clark‚Äôs Iowa team) to [B] Nat‚Äôl Champion in 2023 (defeating Caitlin Clark‚Äôs Iowa team), with the [C] 2023 and 2024 matchups setting various TV viewing records. 2) ‚Ä¶.Angel Reese was essential in [A] sparking an uptick in support LSU/women‚Äôs basketball [B] regardless of age, ethnicity, team allegiance and location (home team averages over 4,000 more fans vs LSU). 3) Scriptural Perspective: ‚Ä¶.From sports to everyday society, they‚Äôre [A] people like Eliab (1 Sam 17:28) who [B] despite "your" proven/winning ways (1-2) will not give ‚Äúyou‚Äù credit and will rather [C] become angry/find something ‚Äúbad‚Äù about you than [D] ‚Äúchampion you‚Äù because [E] ‚Äúit‚Äôs you‚Äù. 4/Q) Scriptural Perspective: ‚Ä¶.As Angel Reese [A] embraced being the ‚Äúbad guy‚Äù, [B] hostility results when no.3 happens (1 Sam 17:28), but [C] did that stop David? (1 Sam 17:29-30) 5) Scriptural Perspective: ‚Ä¶.Whether a Tiger from Hemingway, SC or the Bayou, when one gains [A] joy/fandom in His excellence regardless of opposition (1 Sam 17:28-37; 3-4 above), God will [B] provide opportunities for one to be a championship ‚Äúangel‚Äù (MESSENGER, HARBINGER - Merriam-Webster) with [C] results that‚Äôs proven and louder than a sellout crowd full of Gamecocks/Tigers on the prowl (1 Sam 17:49-53, 18:7; 1-2 above)!! #ScripturalPerspective

If you want stats, look for LeBron. If you want rings, look for Russell. If you want MVPs, look for Kareem. If you want records, look for Wilt. If you want impact, look for Steph. If you want dominance in a position, look for Shaq. If you want perimeter defense, find Gary Payton. If you want athletics, find Kemp, Giannis or Malone. If you want greatness, look for Bird or Magic. If you want exquisite dunks, look for Carter, Dr. J or Wilkins. If you want a good Trash Talker, look for Garnett. If you want influence, look for Iverson. If you want remarkable scoring skills, look for Durant. If you want competitiveness, look for Kobe. If you want Impavidez at Clutch moment, look for Kobe again. Now, if you want a good slice of all that fit to a single player, then look for Michael Jordan.‚úÖ - Source: NBA NEWS AND VIDEOS

This isn't just another draft pick; it's a moment that transcends sports, embodying the power of family, legacy, and perseverance. Father and son, side by side in purple and gold. It's not just a dream anymore ‚Äì it's NBA history in the making. The Los Angeles Lakers just drafted Bronny James, LeBron's eldest son, with the 55th pick in the 2024 NBA Draft. Just a year ago, Bronny faced a life-threatening cardiac arrest. Now, he's on the verge of sharing an NBA court with his father ‚Äì a feat never before accomplished in the league's history. As I look at this powerful image of father and son embracing in Lakers uniforms, I'm struck by the layers of meaning: Dreams realized: LeBron's long-held wish to play alongside his son is now within reach. Overcoming adversity: Bronny's journey from health scare to NBA draft is a testament to resilience. Evolving legacies: We're witnessing the torch being passed in real-time. This moment challenges us to reflect on our own professional journeys: How are we building and extending our legacies? Are we creating opportunities for the next generation in our field? How can we use our success to open doors for others? Let's celebrate this remarkable father-son achievement and consider how we can create our own lasting impact in our professional lives. What does this historic moment inspire in you? Share your thoughts! #NBADraft #Legacy #ProfessionalGrowth

I‚Äôm a big Atlanta Falcons fan! üèà If you‚Äôre still with me after that statement‚Ä¶ When was the last time you took a huge risk in a professional setting? My guess is the answer to that question for Falcons‚Äô Head Coach Arthur Smith is‚Ä¶ yesterday. With time winding down in their game against the Green Bay Packers, his team down by 2 points, they were driving and only needed a field goal to take the lead. There was a huge 4th down looming, in field goal range, Smith decided to go for it! So instead of kicking the field goal that would have potentially given them the lead, the more sure-fire choice and one most people in his position would have made, Smith took a big risk and elected to go for it! I and I‚Äôm pretty sure many other Falcons‚Äô fans were a nervous wreck when we realized he was really going to keep the offense on the field instead of bringing out the kicking team, but you know what? THEY CONVERTED THE FOURTH DOWN! üëè So now, not only does their kicker have an ‚Äúeasier‚Äù field goal, but they leave their opponent with little to no time on the clock to come back. FINAL OUTCOME: THE FALCONS WIN! üéâ When was the last time you bet on yourself and your team the way Arthur Smith did on Sunday? How often do you trust yourself and your team enough to take a big risk for the betterment of the final outcome? My heart is still racing from that play and that choice, but my Falcons flag is flying proudly today because of it! You won‚Äôt always get the positive outcome that played out in Mercedes-Benz Stadium yesterday, but you won‚Äôt even have that chance if you don‚Äôt take the risk! #bigrisk #bigreward #trust #AtlantaFalcons #NFL #ArthurSmith #riskydecision #positiveoutcome #football #Falcons
